case_name: Rameshwar Lal Patwari v. State of Bihar

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 9, 1967 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Writ Jurisdiction Case No. 31 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 9, 1967 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Writ Jurisdiction Case No. 31 of 1967.

facts.text: Rameshwar Lal Patwari applied under Art. 226 of the Constitution and S. 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for a writ or order in the nature of habeas corpus for his release from detention in Bhagalpur Central Jail.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant  Rameshwar Lal Patwari  applied under Art. 226 of the Constitution and S. 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for a writ or order in the nature of habeas companypus for his release from detention in Bhagalpur Central Jail in pursuance of an order of detention passed by the Governor of Bihar on July 4, 1967 under s. 3 1  a  iii  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

facts.text: Order of detention passed by the Governor of Bihar on July 4, 1967 under s. 3(1)(a)(iii) of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: in pursuance of an order of detention passed by the Governor of Bihar on July 4, 1967 under s. 3 1  a  iii  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950. He was arrested under the order on July 11, 1967 and was served on July 13, 1967 with a companyy of the grounds on which his detention was based to enable him to make a representation.

facts.text: Rameshwar Lal Patwari was arrested under the order on July 11, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: He was arrested under the order on July 11, 1967 and was served on July 13, 1967 with a companyy of the grounds on which his detention was based to enable him to make a representation. He made a representation but his release was number recommended.

facts.text: Served with copy of the grounds on July 13, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: and was served on July 13, 1967 with a companyy of the grounds on which his detention was based to enable him to make a representation. He made a representation but his release was number recommended. His application in the High Court was also dismissed.

facts.text: He made a representation but his release was not recommended.

anchor.surface_text: He made a representation but his release was number recommended. His application in the High Court was also dismissed. He number appeals by special leave.

facts.text: His application in the High Court was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: His application in the High Court was also dismissed. He number appeals by special leave. The order of the Governor recites that it is necessary to make an order for his detention to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.

facts.text: He is a prominent businessman of Dumka.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds which were furnished to him were as follows - He is a prominent businessman of Dumka and with the association of Sarvashri Mulchand Choudhury, Kanhaiaya Choudhury, Fulchand Modi, Pir Mohammad  Bengaria P.S.  Shikaripara and others he indulges in black-marketing of foodgrains.

facts.text: Sri Harichandra Agarwala was caught on 29th December, 1966 at Ranibabal near Mashanjor while carrying 95 bags of peddy for illegal trade. In this connection a case under the Essential Commodities Act has been instituted. He is on bail in this case.

facts.text: On the night of 2-2-66, Sri R. S. Singh, 1st Class Magistrate along with Sub-Divisional Officer Sadar, other Magistrate and police officers, raided the house of Sri Rameshwar Lal Patwari and found aft kinds of foodgrains in huge quantity.

anchor.surface_text: On the night of 2-2-66, Sri R. S. Singh, 1st Class Magistrate along with Sub-Divisional Officer Sadar, other Magistrate and police officers, raided the house of Sri Rameshwar Lal Patwari and found aft kinds of foodgrains in huge quantity. His stock register was maintained in irregular way.

facts.text: A case has been instituted in this connection in which he is on bail.

anchor.surface_text: It was found that he has been dealing in foodgrains without any licence. A case has been instituted in this companynection in which he is on bail.

facts.text: The appellant was tried for the offence and acquitted as far back as February 1967.

facts.text: The grounds were challenged by the appellant in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These grounds were challenged by the appellant in the High Court. According to him some of them did number exist in fact and others were vague or irrelevant.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the application.

anchor.surface_text: His application in the High Court was also dismissed.

facts.text: Shri Babu Ram Bikaneria visited Dumka on 26-11-66 and told Rameshwar Lal Patwari to supply gram and gramdal.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Babu Ram Bikaneria, owner of a Rice Mill at Saitha District Birbhum  West Bengal  visited Dumka on 26-11-66 and told him  Sri Rameshwar Lal Patwari  to supply gram and gramdal.

facts.text: On 7/8-12-66 Sri Mulchand Choudhury sent truck No. BRJ 2029 loaded with gram and gramdal to Saitha through Mahesh Kola Check post.

anchor.surface_text: On 7/8- 12-66 Sri Mulchand Choudhury of Rameshwar, who is his agent sent his truck No. BRJ 2029 load- ed with gram and gramdal to Saitha through Mahesh Kola Check post.

facts.text: The appellant has denied that the paddy belonged to him.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has denied that the paddy belonged to him. He pointed out that in the numberice it was admitted that the paddy was being taken to Dumka in Bihar, while in the grounds it was stated that it was on its way to West Bengal

facts.text: Fourth ground refers to a pending case but appellant was acquitted in February 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The fourth ground speaks of a pending case in which the appellant is said to be on bail. The grounds were furnished in July 1967. The appellant was tried for the offence and acquitted as far back as February 1967. This ground discloses carelessness which is extremely disturbing.

facts.text: The Supreme Court quashed the detention order due to defects in grounds.

anchor.surface_text: This case displays both these defects and it is a matter of great regret that powers of detention without a trial, which should be ,exercised with the greatest care and attention have been exercised in this case with such disregard for truth and accuracy.

holdings.text: The courts are not constituted an appellate authority to question the sufficiency of the grounds or the reasonableness of the opinion formed by the detaining authority.

anchor.surface_text: Their satisfaction is all that the law speaks of and the courts are not constituted an appellate authority. Thus the sufficiency of the -rounds cannot be agitated before the court. However, the detention of a person without a trial, merely on the subjective satisfaction of an authority however high, is a serious matter. It must require the closest scrutiny of the material on which the decision is formed, leaving no room for errors or at least avoidable errors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preventive detention relies on subjective satisfaction; courts review only for procedural defects, vagueness, or non-existence of grounds, requiring closest scrutiny to prevent errors.

holdings.text: The grounds of detention must not be vague or indefinite and must afford a real opportunity to the detenu to make a representation against the detention.

anchor.surface_text: the grounds must number be vague or indefinite and must afford a real opportunity to make a representation against the detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detenu has no trial or magistrate production; precise grounds necessary for effective representation to Advisory Board under natural justice.

holdings.text: If a vital ground of detention is shown to be non-existing, such that it could not have and ought not to have influenced the detaining authority's satisfaction, the detention order is vitiated.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, if a vital ground is shown to be number-existing so that it companyld number have and ought number to have played a part in the material for companysideration, the companyrt may attach some importance to this fact. Thus it was in Shibban Lal Saksena v. U.P. that when Government itself companyfirmed the order on one ground rejecting the other, the order was held unsustainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Shibban Lal Saksena and Keshav Talpade precedents, cannot assess weight of grounds or substitute judicial opinion; non-existent ground vitiates entire order.

holdings.text: Indulging in blackmarketing is conduct prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies (and services) essential to the community; 'and' is used disjunctively.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt blackmarketing has at its base a shortening of supplies because blackmarket flourishes best when the availability of companymodities is rendered difficult. It has a definite tendency to disrupt supplies when scarcity exists or scarcity is created artificially by hoarding to attain illegitimate profits. Indulging in blackmarketing is conduct which is prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies. It is hardly necessary to read supplies conjunctively with services as was contended although cases may exist where supplies and services may both be affected. The word and is number used conjunctively but disjunctively.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Blackmarketing shortens and disrupts supplies; disjunctive reading allows detention for supplies alone, per Bhim Sen v. State of Punjab.

holdings.text: The grounds supplied to the detenu were vague, indefinite, irrelevant or non-existing, failing to enable effective representation.

anchor.surface_text: Looked at from this angle, can we say that the detenu was supplied grounds which were number vague or indefinite or irrelevant or number-existing? The grounds are five in number. Putting aside the first and fifth -rounds for the time, we may refer to the second, third and fourth grounds first. The second ground says that his trucks always take to wicked routes to Saithia West Bengal and he himself pilots them. This ground is extremely vague.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second ground lacks specific instances; third lacks details like dates/names; fourth refers to acquitted/closed case; first vague and suspect; fifth vague without connections; prevents effective representation.

holdings.text: Where some grounds of detention are non-existing, vague, cancelled or given up, and lack precision for effective representation, the detention cannot be justified and is vitiated.

anchor.surface_text: The case is thus covered by our rulings that where some grounds are found to be number-existing or -are cancelled or given up, the detention cannot be justified. It is further covered by our decisions that if the grounds are number sufficiently precise and do number furnish details for the purpose of making effective representation the detention can be questioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of precedents to facts showing multiple defective grounds; powers exercised with disregard for truth.

precedents.citation: Shibban Lal Saksena v. U.P. 1 1954 1 S.C.R. 418

anchor.surface_text: Thus it was in Shibban Lal Saksena v. U.P.  1  that when Government itself companyfirmed the order on one ground rejecting the other, the order was held unsustainable. This Court applied the case of the Federal Court in Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 2  and held that the detention on the ground which survived companyld number be .allowed to stand. The following observations may be quoted The detaining authority gave here two grounds for detaining the petitioner. We can neither decide whether these grounds are good or bad, number can we attempt  1   1954 1 S.C.R. 418.

precedents.case_name: Shibban Lal Saksena v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Detention order is vitiated if even one ground is non-existent or illusory, as courts cannot assess the relative contribution of each ground to the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority
precedents.cited_holding: the position would be the same as if one of these, two grounds was irrelevant for the purpose of the Act or was wholly illusory and this would vitiate the detention order as a whole

precedents.citation: Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 2 1943 F.C.R. 88

anchor.surface_text: This Court applied the case of the Federal Court in Keshav Talpade v. The King Emperor 2  and held that the detention on the ground which survived companyld number be .allowed to stand. The following observations may be quoted The detaining authority gave here two grounds for detaining the petitioner. We can neither decide whether these grounds are good or bad, number can we attempt  1   1954 1 S.C.R. 418.  2  1943 F.C.R. 88. to assess in what manner and to what extent each of these grounds operated on the mind of the appropriate authority

precedents.cited_proposition: Cannot substitute objective judicial test for subjective satisfaction of executive; invalid ground vitiates entire detention order

precedents.citation: Bhim Sen v. State of Punjab 1 1952 S.C.R. 19

anchor.surface_text: This case is strongly relied upon by Mr. Setalvad for reasons which will soon appear. The other side relies upon observations in Bhim Sen v. State of Punjab 1  where blackmarketing was companysidered a sufficient ground for detention. No doubt blackmarketing has at its base a shortening of supplies because blackmarket flourishes best when the availability of companymodities is rendered difficult.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt blackmarketing has at its base a shortening of supplies because blackmarket flourishes best when the availability of companymodities is rendered difficult. It has a definite tendency to disrupt supplies when scarcity exists or scarcity is created artificially by hoarding to attain illegitimate profits. Indulging in blackmarketing is conduct which is prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies. It is hardly necessary to read supplies conjunctively with services as was contended although cases may exist where supplies and services may both be affected. The word and is number used conjunctively but disjunctively.
